Boylston Street reopens

Copley area now accessible

Pedestrian traffic trickled onto the once-busy street that had been blocked off by police.

  • Residents return to a moment frozen in time before blasts

Checks have arrived from around the globe, with businesses donating millions and children donating dollars, Mayor Menino said Tuesday.

After a difficult day, Father Chip Hines found solace in the Red Sox game Monday.

Boston Police officers removed street barricades as Boylston Street was re-opened to the public at approximately 3:30a.m. Wednesday Aram Boghosian for the Boston Globe
The memorial to victims of the Marathon bombing was moved to Copley Square before the area reopened this morning. Martine Powers / Globe staff
Bartender Maradyth Mure worked to clean up the mess that was left at Whiskey's Smokehouse. David L. Ryan / Globe staff
Victims of the attack and their families held a vigil Tuesday at the site of the first explosion, near Marathon Sports. Bill Greene / Globe staff
After the vigil at the first Marathon bombing site on Boylston Street, attendees walked to the site of the second blast. Bill Greene / Globe staff
Residents and business owners gathered at the Hynes Convention Center Tuesday before returning to the site. David L. Ryan / Globe staff
After meeting at the Hynes, workers crossed Dartmouth Street to return to begin cleaning their businesses. David L. Ryan / Globe staff
Jake Borash (left) handed off a copy order to father, Edward, of Sir Speedy, after he could not get through security. Dina Rudick / Globe staff
Mike Kincade (left) of Allston filed paperwork at police headquarters to retrieve property lost after the bombing. Dina Rudick / Globe staff
Workers cleaned up at the site of the first Boston Marathon bombing on Boylston Street, scrubbing away on Tuesday. Bill Greene / Globe staff
Boston resident Tracey Fulgan returned to her home on Boylston Street for the first time after the bombings. Bill Greene / Globe staff
Alliea Groupp and brothers Awais Kazi and Abdullah Kazi participated in a vigil at the Islamic Society of Boston. Aram Boghosian / Boston Globe
Richard Corapi of Wakefield held a flag as MIT police officers marched in Stoneham following Sean Collier's funeral. Bill Greene / Globe staff

Thousands to attend slain MIT officer's service

Vice President Joe Biden will be among those in attendance at the memorial service today for MIT police officer Sean Collier. Memorial drive in Cambridge is closed to accommodate the service. (6:25 a.m.)

Amputee Marines bring hope to bombing victims

Sydney Corcoran would have lost her leg if it were not for the tourniquet applied by Matt Smith. Her mother, Celeste, lost both legs below the knee. On Sunday, two visiting amputee Marines brought hope to the Corcorans' hospital beds.
